indicators.label: Imperiled aquatic species

values.label: 4 or more aquatic Species of Greatest Conservation Need (SGCN) observed

indicators.description: Imperiled aquatic species measures the number of aquatic animal Species of Greatest Conservation Need (SGCN) observed within each HUC12 subwatershed. SGCN are identified in State Wildlife Action Plans as most in need of conservation action. This indicator captures patterns of rare and endemic species diversity not well-represented by other freshwater aquatic indicators. It applies only to the estimated floodplain, which spatially defines areas estimated to be inundated by a 100-year flood, also known as the 1% annual chance flood.

indicators.label: Atlantic migratory fish habitat

values.label: Final score of 0 (degraded areas of opportunity)
Final score of 10 (degraded areas of opportunity)
Final score of 70 (areas of excellent fish habitat)
Final score of 80 (areas of excellent fish habitat)

indicators.description: This indicator measures the condition of migratory fish habitat along the Atlantic coast, by catchment. It incorporates metrics of water quality, aquatic connectivity, habitat fragmentation, flow alteration, and more. Areas of excellent fish habitat are already in good condition and face few threats; restoration opportunity areas are doing well in some respects, but restoration projects could significantly improve them; degraded areas of opportunity face many challenges, and restoration projects are unlikely to increase available fish habitat unless particularly large in scope and scale.

indicators.label: Gulf migratory fish connectivity

values.label: Presence of Alabama shad, American shad, or striped bass

indicators.description: Gulf migratory fish connectivity is an index capturing how far upstream migratory fish in the Gulf of Mexico have been observed. Migratory fish presence reflects uninterrupted connections between freshwater, estuarine, and marine ecosystems. This indicator applies only to the estimated floodplain, which spatially defines areas estimated to be inundated by a 100-year flood, also known as the 1% annual chance flood.

indicators.label: Network complexity
indicators.description: Network complexity depicts the number of different stream size classes in a river network not separated by dams or waterfalls. River networks with a variety of connected stream classes help retain aquatic biodiversity in a changing climate by allowing species to access climate refugia and move between habitats. This indicator applies only to the estimated floodplain, which spatially defines areas estimated to be inundated by a 100-year flood, also known as the 1% annual chance flood.

indicators.label: Permeable surface

values.label: Less than 70% of catchment permeable, likely degraded instream flow, water quality, and aquatic species communities
70 - 90% of catchment permeable, likely degraded water quality and not supporting many aquatic species
90 - 95% of catchment permeable, likely declining water quality and supporting most aquatic species
Greater than 95% of catchment permeable, likely high water quality and supporting most sensitive aquatic species

indicators.description: Permeable surface measures the percent of non-impervious cover by catchment. High levels of impervious surface degrade water quality and alter freshwater flow, impacting both aquatic species communities and ecosystem services for people, like the availability of clean drinking water.

indicators.label: Riparian buffers

values.label: Less than 80% natural habitat within the estimated floodplain, by catchment
Greater than 95% natural habitat within the estimated floodplain, by catchment

indicators.description: Riparian buffers measures the amount of natural landcover in the estimated floodplain, by catchment. The estimated floodplain spatially defines areas estimated to be inundated by a 100-year flood, also known as the 1% annual chance flood. Intact riparian buffers are strongly linked to water quality as well as water availability (i.e., instream flow).

indicators.label: Amphibian & reptile areas

values.label: Not a Priority Amphibian and Reptile Conservation Area
Priority Amphibian and Reptile Conservation Area

indicators.description: The amphibian and reptile areas indicator draws from Priority Amphibian and Reptile Conservation Areas (PARCAs). PARCA is an expert-driven, nonregulatory designation that captures places capable of supporting viable amphibian and reptile populations. PARCAs include areas where rare or at-risk species have been observed or are likely to occur (like embedded, isolated wetlands).

indicators.label: Beach birds

values.label: Below the 20th percentile of importance for bird index species
Above the 80th percentile of importance for bird index species (American oystercatcher, Wilson's plover, least tern, and piping plover)

indicators.description: Beach birds is a continuous index of habitat suitability for four shorebird species (Wilson's plover, American oystercatcher, least tern, piping plover), based on observed abundance. The relative use of beach habitat by these species for nesting, foraging, and breeding is an indicator of beach quality.

indicators.label: Equitable access to potential parks

values.label: Area where a new park would create nearby equitable access for 0-1 person
Area where a new park would create nearby equitable access for >1-3 people
Area where a new park would create nearby equitable access for >3-10 people
Area where a new park would create nearby equitable access for >10-50 people
Area where a new park would create nearby equitable access for >50-150 people
Area where a new park would create nearby equitable access for >150-500 people
Area where a new park would create nearby equitable access for >500-2,000 people
Area where a new park would create nearby equitable access for >2,000 people

indicators.description: Equitable access to potential parks measures the number of nearby people within socially vulnerable communities who would benefit from the creation of a new park. This cultural resource indicator depicts undeveloped areas where people currently lack access to protected open space within a short walk (0.5 miles). If conserved and made open to the public, these places would fill gaps in equitable access to open space for underserved residents. Parks help foster a conservation ethic by providing opportunities for people to connect with nature, and also support ecosystem services like offsetting heat island effects, water filtration, stormwater retention, and more.

indicators.label: Fire frequency

values.label: Not burned from 2010-2019 or cultivated cropland

indicators.description: Fire frequency uses remote sensing to estimate the number of times an area has been burned from 2010-2019. Many Southeastern ecosystems rely on regular, low intensity fires to maintain habitat, encourage native plant growth, and reduce wildfire risk.

indicators.label: Forest birds

values.label: Less potential for presence of bird index species
Very small patches or near open areas (potential for presence of wood thrush, whip-poor-will, red-headed woodpecker, Chuck-will’s widow, or American woodcock)
Small patches often near water (potential presence of hooded warbler or Kentucky warbler)
Medium patches (potential for presence of Acadian flycatcher)
Large patches often near water (potential for presence of Northern parula, black-throated green warbler, or Prothonotary warbler)
Very large patches near water (potential for presence of Swainson's warbler)

indicators.description: Forest birds is an index of habitat suitability for twelve upland hardwood and forested wetland bird species (wood thrush, whip-poor-will, American woodcock, red-headed woodpecker, Chuck-will's widow, hooded warbler, Kentucky warbler, Acadian flycatcher, Northern parula, black-throated green warbler, prothonotary warbler, Swainson's warbler) based on patch size and other ecosystem characteristics such as proximity to water and proximity to forest and ecotone edge. The needs of these species are increasingly restrictive at higher index values, reflecting better quality habitat.

indicators.label: Forested wetland extent
indicators.description: Forested wetland extent depicts forested wetlands currently present in the South Atlantic geography. Overall acreage of existing forested wetlands provides an indicator of whether forested wetlands being inundated by sea-level rise are being replaced or restored somewhere else.

indicators.label: Greenways & trails

values.label: Not a greenway, trail, sidewalk, or other path
Partly natural and connected for <1.9 km or developed and connected for 1.9-5 km
Mostly natural and connected for <1.9 km, partly natural and connected for 1.9-5 km, or developed and connected for 5-40 km
Mostly natural and connected for 5-1.9 km, partly natural and connected for 5-40 km, or developed and connected for >40 km
Mostly natural and connected for 5-40 km or partly natural and connected for >40 km
Mostly natural and connected for >40 km

indicators.description: This cultural resource indicator measures both the natural condition and connected length of greenways and trails to characterize the quality of the recreational experience. Natural condition is based on the amount of impervious surface surrounding the path. Connected length captures how far a person can go without leaving a dedicated path, based on common distances for walking, running, and biking.

indicators.label: Intact habitat cores
indicators.description: This indicator represents the size of large, unfragmented patches of natural habitat. It identifies minimally disturbed natural areas at least 100 acres in size and greater than 200 meters wide. Large areas of intact natural habitat benefit numerous species, including reptiles and amphibians, birds, and large mammals.

indicators.label: Low-urban historic landscapes

values.label: Historic place with nearby high-urban buffer
Historic place with nearby low-urban buffer

indicators.description: Low-urban historic landscapes is an index of sites on the National Register of Historic Places surrounded by limited urban development. This cultural resource indicator identifies significant historic places that remain connected to their context in the natural world.

indicators.label: Maritime forest extent
indicators.description: Maritime forest extent depicts maritime forest currently present in the South Atlantic geography. Since maritime forest has been substantially reduced from its historic extent, protecting the remaining acreage of existing maritime forest is important.

indicators.label: Marsh extent
indicators.description: Marsh extent depicts freshwater and saltwater marsh currently present in the South Atlantic geography. Overall acreage provides an indicator of whether marsh being inundated by sea-level rise is being replaced or restored somewhere else.

indicators.label: Marsh birds

values.label: >1-5 ha patch (less potential for presence of marsh bird index species)
>5-20 ha patch (potential for presence of least bittern, Northern pintail, and Northern shoveler)
>20 ha patch (potential for presence of king rail, least bittern, Northern pintail, and Northern shoveler)

indicators.description: Marsh birds is an index based on the size of freshwater and saltwater marsh patches, using patch size thresholds based on the habitat needs of four marsh birds species (least bittern, Northern pintail, Northern shoveler, king rail). Larger, better connected wetland patches protect inland areas from waves during storm events. They also benefit fish, shrimp, and other marsh bird species like saltmarsh sparrow and marsh wren.

indicators.label: Piedmont prairie

values.label: Potentially compatible management (pasture in county with active grassland conservation practices)

indicators.description: This indicator represents Piedmont prairies, which are grasslands with and without trees that once covered most Piedmont uplands and support important plants, birds, and pollinators. It captures known Piedmont prairies; known and predicted glades, outcrops, and interior longleaf habitat; areas of potentially compatible prairie management in power line rights-of-way and pasture; and other grass and pasture locations.

indicators.label: Pine birds

values.label: Less potential for presence of bird index species
Potential for presence of 1 bird index species
Potential for presence of 2 bird index species
Potential for presence of all 3 bird index species (Bachman's sparrow, bobwhite quail, and red-cockaded woodpecker)

indicators.description: Pine birds is an index of habitat suitability for three bird species (Northern bobwhite, red-cockaded woodpecker, Bachman's sparrow) based on observational data and predictive models. The presence of all three species indicates high pine ecosystem quality.

indicators.label: Resilient sites
indicators.description: Resilient sites depicts an area’s capacity to continue supporting species diversity and ecosystem function in the face of climate change. It evaluates the ability of coastal habitats to migrate to adjacent lowlands in response to sea-level rise, based on the physical and condition characteristics of current tidal complexes, their predicted migration space, and surrounding buffer areas—characteristics like marsh complex size, sediment balance, water quality, and many others. In inland terrestrial areas, this indicator measures landscape diversity and local connectedness to identify resilient sites that contain many different microclimates and allow species to move to adjust to changing conditions.

indicators.label: Urban park size
indicators.description: Urban park size measures the size of parks larger than 10 acres in the urban environment. Protected natural areas in urban environments provide urban residents a nearby place to connect with nature, and offer refugia for some species. This indicator complements the equitable access to potential parks indicator by capturing the value of existing parks.

indicators.label: Shoreline condition

values.label: Partially armored and harder to develop

indicators.description: Shoreline condition assesses coastal habitat alteration based on the presence of hardened structures like jetties, groins, and riprap, as well as other human development. Natural shorelines in harder-to-develop coastal areas receive the highest condition scores, while hardened shorelines receive the lowest scores.

indicators.label: Estuarine coastal condition
indicators.description: Estuarine coastal condition is an index of water quality, sediment quality, and benthic community condition that reflects the overall abiotic status of open water estuaries. Developed by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), these measures capture human impacts on the environment like nonpoint source pollution.

indicators.label: Marine birds

values.label: >80th percentile of importance for marine bird index species

indicators.description: Marine birds is a continuous index of highly productive areas for birds that feed exclusively or mainly at sea. It uses seasonal predictions of relative abundance for sixteen species of marine birds (Audubon’s shearwater, white-winged scoter, black scoter, horned grebe, band-rumped storm-petrel, Bermuda petrel, Manx shearwater, black-capped petrel, Northern gannet, Bonaparte's gull. common loon, red-throated loon, Cory's shearwater, royal tern, great shearwater, sooty shearwater, common tern). Marine birds help identify key areas of ocean productivity and complement the marine mammal index by providing finer spatial resolution and stronger connections to forage fish productivity.

indicators.label: Atlantic estuarine fish habitat

values.label: Final score of 0 (degraded areas of opportunity)
Final score of 10 (degraded areas of opportunity)
Final score of 70 (areas of excellent fish habitat)
Final score of 80 (areas of excellent fish habitat)

indicators.description: This indicator measures the condition of estuarine fish habitat along the Atlantic coast. It incorporates metrics of water quality, marsh edges, seagrass and oyster reefs, fragmentation, human development, and more. Areas of excellent fish habitat are already in good condition and face few threats; restoration opportunity areas are doing well in some respects, but restoration projects could significantly improve them; degraded areas of opportunity face many challenges, and restoration projects are unlikely to increase available fish habitat unless particularly large in scope and scale.

indicators.label: Marine mammals

values.label: >80th percentile of importance for marine mammal index species

indicators.description: Marine mammals is a continuous index of dolphin and whale density based on monthly density predictions for ten species of cetaceans and yearly density predictions for three rarer cetacean species (monthly: North Atlantic right whale, sperm whale, Sei whale, humpback whale, fin whale, bottlenose dolphin, short-beaked common dolphin, Risso’s dolphin, harbor porpoise, Atlantic white-sided dolphin; yearly: pilot whale, beaked whale, striped dolphin). Marine mammals help identify key areas of ocean productivity and overall ocean health because they have long life spans, feed at high trophic levels, and can accumulate anthropogenic chemicals and toxins in their large blubber stores.

indicators.label: Hardbottom & deep-sea coral

values.label: Low suitability for coral or hardbottom
Medium suitability for coral or hardbottom
High suitability for coral or hardbottom
Very high suitability for coral or hardbottom

indicators.description: Hardbottom and deep-sea coral measures known and predicted suitable locations of hardbottom habitat and deep-sea corals. Hardbottom provides an anchor for important seafloor habitats such as deep-sea corals, plants, and sponges. Many deep-sea corals form tree-like shapes and complex reefs that provide valuable habitat structure. Hardbottom and associated deep-sea coral communities support a wide range of invertebrate and fish species.
